Sure, here are a few examples of how to call out specific logical fallacies:

1. Ad hominem - "Instead of addressing my argument, you're attacking my character. This is a classic ad hominem fallacy."

2. Straw man - "You're misrepresenting my argument with a simplified or distorted version of it. This is a straw man fallacy."

3. False dilemma - "Your argument presents only two options, and presents them as equally exclusive. This is a false dilemma fallacy."

4. Slippery slope - "Your argument assumes an eventual, unlikely outcome without providing any logical reasoning. This is a slippery slope fallacy."

5. Appeal to authority - "You're relying too heavily on the unproven opinion of an authority figure and ignoring the evidence. This is an appeal to authority fallacy."

6. Hasty generalization - "You're basing your argument on a single example or a limited set of data, which is not enough to support such a broad conclusion. This is a hasty generalization fallacy."

By understanding these fallacies and calling them out, you can effectively weaken your opponent's argument and build a stronger case for your own position.
